query.result: | Italian | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | Domenico | Greek | From the Greek name Δομένικος (Doménikos), meaning "belonging to the Lord". | | essere | Latin | From the Latin verb esse, meaning "to be". | | dire | Latin | From the Latin verb dicere, meaning "to say". | | e | Latin | From the Latin conjunction et, meaning "and". | | io | Latin | From the Latin pronoun ego, meaning "I". | | ne | Latin | From the Latin particle ne, used to introduce a question or negation. | | parlare | Latin | From the Latin verb parlare, meaning "to speak". | | sì | Latin | From the Latin adverb sic, meaning "so" or "yes". | | come | Latin | From the Latin adverb quomodo, meaning "how". | | di | Latin | From the Latin preposition de, meaning "of" or "from". | | il | Latin | From the Latin definite article ille, meaning "the". | | agricoltore | Latin | From the Latin words ager (field) and cultor (cultivator). | | che | Latin | From the Latin relative pronoun qui, quae, quod, meaning "who", "which", or "that". | | Cristo | Greek | From the Greek word Χριστός (Christós), meaning "anointed one". | | eleggere | Latin | From the Latin verb eligere, meaning "to choose". | | a | Latin | From the Latin preposition ad, meaning "to" or "at". | | il | Latin | From the Latin definite article ille, meaning "the". | | orto | Latin | From the Latin word hortus, meaning "garden". | | suo | Latin | From the Latin possessive adjective suus, sua, suum, meaning "his", "her", or "its". | | per | Latin | From the Latin preposition per, meaning "through" or "by". |

query.prompt:
For each row in the table, look up the etymology of the word. In the "Derived" column, write Latin, Greek, Germanic, etc. In the "Etymology" column, fill in the corresponding word in Greek, Latin, or others, but leave blank if unknown.
| Italian | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | e | | | | muovere | | | | meco | | | | questo | | | | compagnia | | |
query.result:
| Italian | Derived | Etymology | |---|---|---| | e | Latin | et | | muovere | Latin | movere | | meco | Latin | mecum | | questo | Latin | eccum istum | | compagnia | Latin | cum+panis |
**Notes:**
* The etymology of "e" is simply the Latin word "et", meaning "and". * The etymology of "muovere" is the Latin verb "movere", meaning "to move". * The etymology of "meco" is the Latin phrase "mecum", meaning "with me". * The etymology of "questo" is the Latin phrase "eccum istum", meaning "behold this one". * The etymology of "compagnia" is the Latin phrase "cum+panis", meaning "with bread". This is because, in ancient Rome, soldiers would often share their bread with their comrades, and this sharing of food came to symbolize companionship.
